title: Xiang Lin Si Temple
text:
Xiang Lin Si Temple () is a <a href="Chinese%20temple">Chinese temple</a> located opposite of <a href="Cheng%20Hoon%20Teng%20Temple">Cheng Hoon Teng Temple</a> in Jalan Tokong, <a href="Malacca%20City">Malacca City</a>. This double-storey temple follows the <a href="Buddhist">Buddhist</a> branch of <a href="Mah%C4%81y%C4%81na%20Buddhism">Mahāyāna Buddhism</a>.
History.
The temple is named after a <a href="Buddhist%20monk">monk</a> from <a href="China">China</a>, started as a "<a href="kampung">village</a>"-style wooden house in 1958 before being rebuilt in a modern architecture as a double-storey brick building in 1985.
Features.
The two-storey temple has a three <a href="arch">arch</a> doorways on each level. In the first doorway which is the Buddha Hall, there is a small smiling statue of Mi-lo Fwo (<a href="Maitreya">Maitreya</a>) in a short altar facing the door. The <a href="Eighteen%20Arhats">Eighteen Luohan</a> are lined up on both sides of the Buddha Hall, nine on each side, leading to a smaller statue of <a href="Gautama%20Buddha">Gautama Buddha</a> in the centre. Behind the Buddha statues is the statue of <a href="Goddess%20of%20Mercy">Goddess of Mercy</a> (Guan Yin). The temple also kept a complete collection of the <a href="P%C4%81li%20Canon">Pāli Canon</a>, a religious scripture of Buddhism. The second floor of the temple is a convenient spot for capturing scenic photos of its neighbouring temple of Cheng Hoon Teng and the rest of the "Harmony Street" because of its proximity to the <a href="Kampung%20Kling%20Mosque">Kampung Kling Mosque</a> and <a href="Sri%20Poyatha%20Moorthi%20Temple">Sri Poyatha Moorthi Temple</a>, which symbolises religious tolerance existed long before the founding of the modern state of Malaysia.
